history.content:
162 is not a class to be underestimated. You'll have periods of weeks where it's just back to back hw, project, midterm, project deadlines. Even with a solid group it is a tough load. You'll be taking that with another project (hw) heavy class 186. 7A is a problemset class, but it's from Mastering physics. While it's not as demanding as other pset classes like 170, don't underestimate it, because the curve for physics classes is generally lower. 

I can't speak to the second schedule you're taking because it depends on the R5B and HSS you're taking. In all it's a doable workload, taking those 3 classes, but it's important to stay on top of lecture, especially for 186 and 162, as the exams often test material that is not implemented in the projs and hws

children.subject: they've increased the difficulty of 186 projects in recent semesters though, so I'd still consider it a moderate load.

I think this is a very doable workload. 

186 is probably the lightest CS class I have taken at Cal; I have to disagree with the student answer that it is a project "heavy" class. 162 is a lot of work indeed, but 7A should be nothing too tough if you've seen the concepts before
How is physics 7a for someone who has only take AP Physics C (mechanics)?

history.content: I was wondering if 162, 186 and Physics 7A next fall would be too heavy a workload if I have a decent amount of commitment outside of academics and want to do well. How heavy would such a schedule be compared to 170 + Data 100 + R5B + H/SS (my current schedule)? For what it's worth I have encountered most, if not all, of the topics in 7A previously, but I'm unfamiliar with the structure of questions asked on exams.
history.subject: 162 + 186 + 7A?
